New Records: James Rodríguez scored from the penalty spot and had an assist, helping Colombia edge Argentina 2-1 in their South American World Cup qualifier match.
Colombia's James Rodríguez became the first player to reach 11 assists in South American World Cup qualifying, matching Carlos Valderrama's record.
Colombia's Camilo Vargas made several key saves, including stopping a penalty by Argentina's Dibu Martínez, which was the first penalty saved by Vargas in a major tournament since his debut in 2015.
Key Match Events: Colombia opened the scoring with Yerson Mosquera's goal in the 25th minute.
Argentina equalized in the 48th minute after Nico González capitalized on a defensive error by Colombia.
James Rodríguez scored a decisive penalty in the 60th minute after a video review, securing Colombia's win.
Colombia had not beaten Argentina since 2019 before this match.
Pre-Game Insights: Argentine striker Lionel Messi did not play in the match due to an injury.
Colombia relied on James Rodríguez's experience and leadership in the match.
The match was the first between the two teams since the Copa América final in 2021.
Post-Match Reflections: Colombia coach Nelson Quintana praised Rodríguez's performance and the team's resilience.
Argentina's manager Scaloni acknowledged Colombia's fighting spirit and the challenge of playing without Messi.
The match highlighted the importance of key players in international football.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was part of South American World Cup qualifying for 2026.
Colombia remained unbeaten in the qualifying round-robin tournament.
The result kept Argentina at the top of the standings with 18 points, two points ahead of Colombia.
Others: The match was held at the Metropolitano Roberto Melendez stadium in Barranquilla, Colombia.
